history.content: It would probably be a good idea to research what classes the EE bachelor's degree students take at the school you're applying to. If they're doing a lot of hardware and you don't have much of a hardware background, that might not be a good fit. However, if the school is strong in robotics, and you've done coursework in robotics, you could make a case that you're a good applicant.

As an EE major, I believe so. People move around engineering disciplines for grad school all the time so it shouldn't be a problem as long as you are well prepared.

You'll definitely need 105, 120, and 151 to be competitive (basic competency in signal processing, analog/digital circuits), but the good news is that these classes satisfy the L&S CS major requirements as "CS" classes so it's a win-win. Nobody cares about the title of your degree as long as you have requisite coursework.

I'm majoring in L&S CS and after graduating I'm strongly considering doing an electrical engineering master's program, here or at a different university. Since most of the CS coursework focuses on the 'software' side of EECS but I'm more interested in studying the 'hardware' side, do you think I would qualify as meeting the prerequisites for admission or would it be seen as not relevant enough classwork? As a side note, even if I did meet the admission prerequisites, would my choice of major as CS instead of EE probably make me less competitive for admission?

Also, I'm currently pursuing a double major in CS and applied math, but I'm strongly considering switching to a double major in CS and MCB for a variety of reasons. Would this significantly impact my odds of getting into an EE master's program?
history.subject: Would an L&S CS major meet the prerequisites for an EE master's program?
